did.unittitle: Poster collection
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Collection assembled by the staff of UCLA Library Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Poster Collection (Collection 95). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of an assemblage of posters, primarily 20th century American and European. Includes travel posters, exhibit posters, and war posters from World War I France, and American posters from World War I and World War II.

did.unittitle: Les Alsaciens et les Lorrains sont Français! [text blocks]. Paris : J. Cussac, Imp., [1914].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Signed in lower right of image: "L. Jonas". At lower left: "VISA No. 11.922". Alsace and Lorraine were lost to Germany in the Franco-Prussian war of 1870-71 (from LC record). Block of text below image is regarding the history of the Alscae-Lorraine region and its association to the rest of France. LC has this poster and alternate version with different title and text block but same image. Date from LC record.

France toujours! / France quand même! / Car la France est eternelle, et rien de ce qui est la France ne saurait périr. [S.l.] : Demoulin Frères. SC., [19--] (Paris : Editions Delandre).

A special national day for the benefit of veterans who were suffering from tuberculosis (from LC record). Date from LC record.

did.unittitle: La journée du Poilu. Paris : I. Lapina. Imp. Edit., 1915.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Medallions on both sides of title. Left one reads: 25 Décembre 26 Décembre 1915 Le Poilu. Right one has image of a soldier head in profile (Poilu?) in front of a female statue head in profile with the words 'Le Poilu' underneath. Under title in center of image is a close-up of a notecard which presumably came with the package the soldier in the image is opening. It reads: "Avec vous et par vous nous jourons de sauver la France. Leon Gambetta." Signed in lower right of image: "L. Jonas". Léon Gambetta (1838-1882) was one of the founders of the Third Republic and was regarded as one of the heroes of the Franco-Prussian War of 1870-71. He became premier of France for a short while in 1881 (from LC record).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Signed in lower right of image, under soldier's foot: "Maurice Neumont 1918". In lower left next to printer: "VISA No. 13.037". Poison gas was first used in WWI. The phrase 'they shall not pass' is said to have originated with General Robert Nivelle (1856-1924) at the battle of Verdun in 1916 (from LC record). LC has 1917 edition of this poster, artist's signature is different.
